ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Several student-led seminar discussions; one asynchronous class meeting

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about molecular, statistical, and computational methods to investigate hominid populations, and their relations and migrations.

We learned about the various ways studying DNA can be used to understand human history, such as plagues, evolution, and population migrations. We also learned about gene sequencing and editing technologies such as Sanger Sequencing, PCR, and CRISPR.

Basic concepts of genetics, how to read scientific peer-reviewed articles, Neanderthals and Denisovans, models of human migrations (e.g. Out-of-Africa model, Multiregional model), how ancient DNA is extracted and analyzed, how genes and culture are linked, ethics/ethical concerns regarding molecular anthropology research
A deeper understanding of how genetics influence evolution and modern humans.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would be good to have more lecture material and only 20 or 30 minutes for questions each class. Sometimes grades were not handed back in a timely fashion. The course should be more organized with concrete themes.

The first half of the class was essentially a review of basic genetic concepts and could be shortened to allow for more focus on molecular anthropology. In the second half though, the class did take a turn to teach new and interesting concepts, such as studying ancient DNA to identify causes of plagues and how language trees and human migration patterns can be very similar.

Strengths: the topics and readings we covered were super interesting and the guest lecturers were awesome (especially Adam Rutherford); tests always reflected what was covered in class lectures; the professor is really sweet and incredibly responsive to suggestions/improvements; professor and TF graded pretty generously, which helped relieve some stress throughout the semester with regards to COVID
Weaknesses: because it was a small class, it became more discussion-based, and discussions weren't as fluid as my other discussion-based classes; wish I got more feedback on tests and presentations
Strengths include the readings and projects.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything seemed to work well, from student presentations to paper submissions. The two exams we had to do were a little strange since they were done on a Word document and not on Canvas, but it still worked out fine.

Reviewing for exams went really smoothly because the lecture slides were always posted in a timely manner. Most of the papers that we were required to read were also uploaded in a timely manner (at least a week in advance, usually).
We also had one asynchronous class meeting in early November, which was much appreciated.
The live discussions were an effective mode of learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend this course if they have a real interest in human populations, and the methods that are used to analyze human DNA.

If you are interested in studying DNA in an anthropological context, this is a great course to help you understand the myriad of ways that it can be used and help you decided what courses to take in the future.
I would recommend this course for non-biology majors that want an easy-going introduction to genetic concepts and evolution.
Yes, very highly. The format of the class and the material were very engaging.
